ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Each class was discussion based with groups of students doing a presentation/leading discussions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the global pharmaceutical industry and its shortcomings, specifically in low and middle income countries. The final paper helped me develop my research skills and ability to read and synthesize scientific articles.
I learned a lot about the pharmaceutical industry and its current failings.

I learned a great deal about how the current patent regime makes medicines too expensive and how lowering the price of drugs would lead to a lack of incentive for pharmaceutical firms to invest in research and drug development. The alternative to this dilemma is creating an international institution to provide incentives for drug companies to lower prices while receiving a financial reward for the health impact they achieve.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Could use more feedback so that students know how they are doing throughout the course of the semester
The student led and discussion based formal was very different and refreshing.

There was an exceptional amount of lecture for a seminar.  The readings were often repetitive and from incomplete literature-- the book we read for the class was a draft with references and editing notes instead of useful information in some places.  Throughout the semester small groups of students gave presentations discussing a chapter from the unfinished book that lasted the entirety of the 110 minute seminar.
I would have benefitted from more discussion.
all strengths - fantastic class and concept

Strengths: develop a deep understanding of the patent system in regards to pharmaceutical companies and possible alternative frameworks that could help the status quo. Great chance to work with other students as well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All the reading materials were posted online for free, which was very nice.
There wasn't enough engagement for me, personally.  We rarely had discussions which would have improved the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, professor Pogge is a wonderful and well-informed professor, a highlight of my Yale career

Yes, I think this course gave a very realistic view of the pharmaceutical industry and how it can be improved. This would be good for anyone who is committed to improving health outcomes in poorer countries and social justice.
I would not.  I was not able to learn anything I couldn't have just read from the internet because of the low class engagement.

Yes- if you are interested in ways in which the current pharmaceutical patent system could be influenced to help develop treatments for diseases burdening low-to-middle income countries. Offers very insightful and current work.
